subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today I'd
like to talk about the experimenter
effect. It's well known in the behavioral
sciences and in medicine that
researchers have the ability to
influence the subjects in their
studies. They can do it in simple
ways, you know, through nonverbal
communication, a smile, a gesture, a hint, a
different language here and there.
That's one of the main reasons why in
the behavioral sciences, certainly in
medical testing for drugs and other
things, we use control groups and we use
a double-blind so that if you have a
control group and an experimental test
group, neither the subjects nor the
researchers have any idea who was in
which group. It's chosen by a random
selection process and the participants
are protected from having any
information about that. That seemed
like a pretty good control for most
scientific research. The double blind
was
considered like the gold standard for
decades.
Some people go a little further, [they] use
a triple blind, which means that even
participants like research assistants
and other people who are
peripherally connected to the research
don't know anything about it. But then in
recent years, there's been some blowback
that the double-blind is not sufficient
to protect against what are called
questionable research practices, QRPs.
For example, and there are many of them,
but one example which I think will make
the point is called optional stopping. If
I'm running an experiment, I'm hoping for
a certain result. Most researchers do,
after all, have what you could call their
cherished
hypotheses. If the experiment is
progressing and the results look good,
well, why not just stop right then
and there rather than complete a set number
of experimental trials. Sometimes
experimenters have been basically caught
doing that. They don't specify in advance
how many trials they're going to run, so
when the experiment stops, they just say
this is the number of trials we had
and the statistics are such and such. But,
by optionally choosing when the
experiment will stop that actually
invalidates many of the statistics that
are used. So, a lot of research is being
called into question now because of that,
not just in the behavioral and social
sciences and in the medical
and biological sciences but even, I think, to
some degree in physics, the
question of optional stopping is
still a real issue across the board.
As a result of that, people in academia,
people in science, are calling into
question many long-standing findings
that have been well accepted and they're
beginning to wonder: how good is the
replication rate on these findings
and what do you make of replications
that are not precise, exact replications,
but are what we call conceptual
replications? Can they be trusted, or
is the concept being tested actually a
different concept? So, I think it's fair
to say that, especially in the behavioral
sciences, but all across the scientific
community, there's a lot of turmoil.
There is a lot of questioning about: how
good has the science that has been
reported over the decades actually been?
How much do we have to actually start
over and redo all of science? Of
course, that fits into the cultural mood
these days where
all sorts of authorities are being
questioned.
We never know whether our politicians
are being truthful to us. Now, people
are questioning the media. So, where does
it end?
Can you trust
science at all? It's a big issue with
regard to such things as global warming.
Now, parapsychology though introduces a
whole additional level at which the
experimenter effect may occur. Because,
if we assume, as parapsychologists
tend to assume, that extrasensory
perception and psychokinesis are real,
how can we rule out an experimenter
using their own precognition
clairvoyance, telepathy, and psychokinesis
to influence the experiment they're
running in order to favor their
cherished hypothesis? The truth is, we
don't know any way to protect against
this. That is a very profound realization.
And it's one, I have to say, that
frightens people in the behavioral
sciences and social sciences. That's why
I think this group of people is the most
hostile of any group of academics to the
field of parapsychology because,
obviously, if psychic phenomena are real,
as parapsychologists - I don't even want
to say parapsychologists claim this, I
want to say it this way - as the data of
parapsychology would lead us to
believe, then is there any reason to rule
out the possibility that conventional
social science, behavioral science
researchers are influencing their own
studies, not only through questionable
research practices, not only by subtle
verbal cues, but through psi?
That really will be like throwing a
monkey wrench into the scientific
establishment, particularly as I have
said now over and over again, behavioral
and social sciences, or cognitive sciences as
they are now called. But, I'm really
referring to psychology and all of its
many forms and branches. So, how do you
get around the experimenter effect in
parapsychology? I have an answer to that.
It's very simple. The experimenter
effect, the whole notion of a cherished
hypothesis, becomes particularly
important when we're talking about
process-oriented research. In other words,
we want to know how something works, how
for example, clairvoyance, precognition,
works. We like to look at personality
variables. I've already reported about
the sheep-goat effect, for example, as an
important personality variable in
parapsychology, and also in other fields
as well. So, a lot of research in
parapsychology is process-oriented
research. Normally we say this, well,
if a particular researcher has a
cherished hypothesis and uses his, let us say,
psychokinesis, in order to influence the
experiment and get the result that
favors his cherished hypothesis even
though the process may have nothing to
do with the process of the hypothesis at
all. It's experimenter psi. If that's the
case, then certain kinds of studies are
immune from that, ones that don't have
process-oriented hypotheses. If I simply
want to prove that ESP exists, that under
a certain set of conditions I can run an
experiment and make sure that there's no
possibility of sensory leakage, no
possibility of
cheating of any sort, and get a
statistically significant result, at
least one can say that I have
established the existence of a
scientific anomaly. I'll take it one
step further. If I'm looking at the
strength of the phenomena, that can be
measured. It doesn't matter what the
source of the phenomenon was or the
process of the phenomenon was as long as
we rule out non-paranormal sources.
Then we can look at the magnitude of the
phenomena. I think that's very important,
especially for applied research.
However, in other fields of science,
that's not necessarily the case. And so,
anthropology, sociology, economics,
business research, all of those fields of
science are vulnerable to the accusation,
if parapsychology were to become widely
accepted, that their findings might be
the result of psi, not the hypotheses
that they were actually testing. Now, as I
was starting to say earlier, if a
researcher does get a significant result
and people wonder, did they do it through
psi, well, the way in which
parapsychologists today deal with that
is, if they want to do process-
oriented research, is to say, "Well, let's
see how well it replicates, how many
different laboratories come up with the
same finding." One assumes that if
many of your colleagues are able to
replicate the finding, then it's probably
because of the hypothesis you're testing
and not because of surreptitious psi
influencing your data. But, what if
there's a widespread cultural bias in
favor of your hypothesis so that every
laboratory running that test has the
same emotional bias you
do. Maybe the sheep-goat, maybe it's the case
that all of the parapsychologists
testing the sheep-goat effect really
held in their hearts a belief, a
belief system, the belief that you
can or that you cannot score well in an
ESP test will affect the test. And so,
using psychokinesis
they surreptitiously, even unconsciously,
unbeknownst to themselves, influence
their study to get that result. If we
look at that seriously it would tend to
make us call into question all
process-oriented research, not only in
parapsychology but in all other fields
as well. That would result in
such a shake-up of the scientific community
that it's understandable to a degree why
so many people in academia, particularly
in the sciences, are hostile or
indifferent to the field of
parapsychology. Why is it that we have
135+ years of
rigorous research that is almost
entirely ignored by the larger community?
So, I hope that this discussion has been
edifying for you. But, you might ask
yourself, what does it mean for you?
How is the experimenter effect in
conventional science and in
parapsychology going to make any
difference whatsoever in your life?
You might start by asking yourself this:
what are the kind of research findings
that you hold and accept without
question? For example, the finding
that taking a baby aspirin every day can
help reduce heart disease and heart
attacks, it's a statistical finding, a
process-oriented
finding. There are thousands of such
research findings, thousands of them
published every year. Do you accept
these findings? Do you think that you
should call them into question? What
about the issue of magnitude in
parapsychology? What are the outer limits
of psychic functioning and why aren't
parapsychologists paying more attention
to that sort of research? Wouldn't we
benefit more by understanding how much
magnitude it is possible to generate in
a research context or even in a field
setting? I'll leave you with those
thoughts. Thank you for being with me.
